content.title: Pain Assessment in the ICU
content.summary: Pain affects 50-80% of ICU patients and is frequently undertreated due to communication barriers. Modern critical care emphasizes 'analgesia-first' approaches, using validated behavioral pain scales (BPS, CPOT) for non-communicative patients. Self-report remains gold standard when possible. Multimodal analgesia combining opioids with non-opioid adjuncts (acetaminophen, gabapentinoids, regional anesthesia) reduces opioid exposure and side effects. Adequate pain control reduces delirium, facilitates ventilator weaning, and improves outcomes.
key_points: Self-report is gold standard; use 0-10 numeric scale when patient can communicate
BPS and CPOT for non-communicative patients; validated behavioral scales
Analgesia-first: treat pain BEFORE adding sedation
Multimodal approach: opioid + non-opioid adjuncts reduces opioid requirements
Untreated pain increases delirium, prolongs mechanical ventilation
Procedural pain: pre-emptive analgesia before procedures (dressing changes, turns)
content.statement: ICU pain assessment uses self-report when possible and validated behavioral scales (BPS, CPOT) when not, with analgesia-first multimodal approaches reducing opioid exposure, delirium, and ventilator days.

explanation.intuition: Pain is often invisible in sedated ICU patients - they can't tell us they hurt. Using behavioral signs (facial expression, body movements, ventilator fighting) through validated scales gives us eyes to see pain. Treating pain first often reduces the need for sedation.
explanation.key_insight: The 'analgesia-first' paradigm is game-changing. Many patients labeled as 'agitated' are actually in pain. Treating pain before reaching for sedatives reduces medication exposure, shortens ventilator time, and decreases delirium. Pain drives the stress response.
explanation.technical_details: BPS (Behavioral Pain Scale) scores facial expression, upper limb movements, and ventilator compliance (3-12 scale; ≥5 suggests pain). CPOT (Critical Care Pain Observation Tool) adds vocalization and muscle tension (0-8 scale; ≥3 suggests pain). Both validated in intubated patients unable to self-report.

definitions_glossary.BPS: Behavioral Pain Scale; validated tool for intubated patients (3-12)
definitions_glossary.CPOT: Critical Care Pain Observation Tool; 0-8 scale for non-verbal patients
definitions_glossary.numeric_rating_scale: 0-10 patient self-report scale; gold standard when applicable
definitions_glossary.analgesia_first: Treat pain before adding sedation; reduces medication exposure
definitions_glossary.multimodal_analgesia: Combining opioids with non-opioid adjuncts for synergistic effect
definitions_glossary.procedural_pain: Pain from ICU procedures (line placement, dressing changes, turns)
definitions_glossary.fentanyl: Synthetic opioid; rapid onset, short duration; preferred in hemodynamic instability
definitions_glossary.hydromorphone: Semi-synthetic opioid; less histamine release than morphine
definitions_glossary.ketamine: NMDA antagonist; provides analgesia and sedation; opioid-sparing
definitions_glossary.regional_anesthesia: Nerve blocks, epidurals; highly effective, opioid-sparing
definitions_glossary.patient_controlled_analgesia: PCA; patient-administered boluses for pain control

pain_epidemiology.prevalence: 50-80% of ICU patients experience significant pain

self_report.gold_standard: Patient's own report is most accurate
self_report.when_to_use: Any patient who can communicate reliably

physiologic_indicators.limitation: NOT reliable alone - can be absent in pain or present without pain

fentanyl.advantages: Rapid onset; no histamine release; short duration
fentanyl.considerations: Accumulates with prolonged infusion; chest wall rigidity at high doses

hydromorphone.advantages: Less histamine than morphine; suitable for renal impairment

remifentanil.advantages: Ultra-short acting; esterase metabolism; no accumulation

acetaminophen.IV_dose: 1 g every 6 hours (max 4 g/day; reduce in liver disease)

NSAIDs.use: Limited in critical illness due to risks

gabapentinoids.role: Neuropathic pain; opioid-sparing in surgical patients

pharmacologic: Ketamine bolus for repeated painful procedures

opioid_tolerant_patients.baseline_requirements: May need higher doses; calculate baseline and add
opioid_tolerant_patients.avoid_withdrawal: Continue baseline plus additional for acute pain

elderly.risk: Higher sensitivity to opioid side effects

definition.@value: Assessment and management of pain in critically ill patients using self-report and behavioral scales with multimodal analgesia

scopeNote.@value: ABCDEF bundle component A: Assess, prevent, manage pain

learning_objectives: Apply BPS and CPOT scales for non-verbal pain assessment
Design multimodal analgesia regimen reducing opioid exposure
Provide pre-emptive analgesia for ICU procedures
Recognize consequences of undertreated pain in critical illness
clinical_pearls: Self-report is gold standard; use BPS/CPOT only when patient cannot communicate
BPS ≥5 or CPOT ≥3 suggests clinically significant pain
Analgesia-first: treat pain before adding sedation - reduces delirium
Fentanyl preferred in hemodynamic instability (no histamine release)
Morphine accumulates in renal failure - avoid or reduce dose
common_misconceptions: Vital signs reliably indicate pain - they are not specific or sensitive
Sedation treats pain - sedation masks pain; treat pain first
All opioids are equivalent - they differ in metabolism and side effects
